eighth.title: DC Food court
eighth.location: Location - food court of the Distribution Center

text.1: Street cages have been installed where used plastic bottles can be thrown away, pre-cleaned and crumpled to a flat state or twisted to take up less space.
text.2: The collected plastic is sent for recycling and reuse.

text.1: This is our Office's green lungs, where you can relax in a natural area during a break or hold a working meeting in the open air.
text.2: There are pedestrian walkways and benches with a canopy.
text.3: Trees in the park create a cozy atmosphere and a pleasant shade from the sun. Green spaces have a positive impact on the urban climate, retain dust and gases, and thus contribute to air purification.

reception.title: Boxes for collecting used batteries and disposable e-cigarettes

text.1: Used batteries contain a number of dangerous toxic components, such as lead, manganese, lithium, and zinc.
text.2: If they are dumped in conventional landfills instead of being recycled, the toxins begin to poison water and soil, as well as plants growing nearby.
text.3: Disposable e-cigarettes pose no less of a threat to the environment, as their consumption has increased dramatically in recent years, aggravating the problem of their disposal.
text.4: By throwing used batteries into special boxes, you take care of safe disposal. And used e-cigarette batteries become raw materials for reuse.

text.1: Containers for waste sorting (bio, metal, glass, plastic, waste paper and other waste) are installed.
text.2: Sorting helps to turn waste into a resource: to make things or energy from it, and to reduce the number of landfills, and thus protect ecosystems from destruction.

text.1: The food court also has a food waste shredder under the sink - an eco-friendly solution for recycling leftovers.
Containers for waste sorting (bio, metal, glass, plastic, waste paper and other waste) are installed.
text.2: Sorting helps to turn waste into a resource: to make things or energy from it, and to reduce the number of landfills, and thus protect ecosystems from destruction.

text.1: Here, used and collected waste paper and stretch wrap are pressed into compact bales, which reduces their volume by several times.
text.2: This helps to free up storage space. This makes it easier to transport recyclables for further processing and reuse.
